subject: Re: tests do not run after adding another suite to AllTests
msgSnippet: ... Haven t tried, yet. Still really busy cleaning up after one migration while trying to complete another migration. Ow! I thought I d have time yesterday,
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
>
> On 11/8/06, bill turner <bill.turner@...> wrote:
> >
> > Yes, I am using ant under cygwin on windows xp. I have not tried
> > running from command line, nor from within Eclipse, which obviously
> > implies not running from a debugger. I am not sure how I would do that
> > in Eclipse, to tell you the truth. I have never done this, but see my
> > junit recipes book discusses running tests from within eclipse. I'll
> > give that a try later today.
>
>
>
> How'd that go?
>
>
Haven't tried, yet. Still really busy cleaning up after one migration
while trying to complete another migration. Ow! I thought I'd have
time yesterday, but... Anyway, I'll probably give it a shot over the
weekend.

> I did comment out the various AllTests and found the offender. That
> > AllTest only executed one test. So, I added a target for the one
> > offending test class. When running that, the response is the same as
> > below. It appears to be not running the test at all.
>
>
In the heat of things yesterday, I did trigger my AllTest that had the
offending sub AllClass's commented out. This had worked in the past
but it seems it did not yesterday. However, I cannot be sure. Testing
wasn't critical at the moment (I had meant to call a different target
to jar and deploy), so I didn't research. Possibly I was mistaken
about the state of the test.

>
> Can you share anything about the test class that is causing the pain?
>
Assuming I am correct in identifying the failing class, no, there is
nothing really significant about the class. I have one test. It
returns an int. I assert that the value returned is what is expected.
The underlying class, likewise, is nothing very special. Testing via
other means demonstrates that it works just fine.

The problem has to be something simple, something obvious, I am
overlooking. Hmmmm... Unfortunately, there are no other eyes I can
share with. I am the only geek here nor have I really developed
friendships with others in the java/junit community locally with whom
I would feel comfortable sitting down with and working through it. I
guess that is what happens when one is independent and does not live
in Silicon Valley ;-)

> Good luck,
>
> David Saff
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
